Fields.DialogueText: Nagato, I was looking for you! The lookouts on watch spotted a Funayūrei heading towards the coast.
Nagato? Are you ready for the chase?
... Oh. Forgive me, Kanchou, my thoughts were elsewhere.
Are you well?
Of course, Kanchou. You should call all hands to stations.

Fields.MenuText: If something is the matter, I want to help you. Please tell me.
I know you tend to withdraw when something's on your mind.
I'm your captain. You can't just brush me off like that.

Fields.DialogueText: There's nothing wrong, I just had a disturbing thought.
Hm. You can worry about what is on my mind later.
We have a battle to win, Kanchou.
We'll talk after the fight.
@BATTLE
That wasn't so bad. Now, what's on your mind, Nagato?
... You look tired, Kanchou. I was overanalyzing... some things. I won't burden you with such thoughts at the moment.
Do you see that? The smoke on the horizon?
May I see your binoculars?
Here.
Hmm... it looks as if several ships have been set aflame...
Sharp eyes. As far as I know, there aren't any other Protection Force vessels in the area, so they're likely civilian ships.
Preyed upon by Funayūrei. Or your average pirates, taking advantage of the chaos.
... No. It was a Funayūrei, and she's still lurking nearby, I can feel her. Do we approach, Kanchou?

Fields.MenuText: Of course. It's our duty to combat any Morgana we run across.
Of course. We cannot allow civilian ships to become easy targets for the Funayūrei.
It's our duty to help the ships in peril, at very least.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm eager to cut my teeth on another one of their hulls, Kanchou.
You're right. These are our waters, and those people are ours to protect.
It's common decency. I only hope we get there in time!
@BATTLE
That was a quick fight. They didn't seem very eager to face you, Nagato.
Perhaps they already got what they wanted from these ships.
Kanchou, there's a lifeboat off my bow! It looks like a few civilian crew members managed to escape.
The lifeboat looks worse for wear...
It's taking water quickly. Kanchou, please instruct the crew to prepare their own lifeboats to retrieve the survivors!
Until then, I'll do what I can.
How was I to expect "I'll do what I can" to mean "I'll leap off the bow into the dangerous waters myself?"
I didn't see any other option, Kanchou. Those people would have drowned.
... Some of them did drown. I couldn't help many.

Fields.MenuText: That was a brave act, Nagato. I'm proud of you.
I didn't know you were capable of being quite so... impetuous.
Had you ever attempted swimming in your solid state before?

Fields.DialogueText: ... Thank you, Kanchou. To tell you the truth, I don't know what came over me.
I-I don't know what came over me. I probably should have thought it through before I jumped in.
Ha... no. I'm not entirely sure what would have happened had I not instinctively known how to swim.
I only wish I could have done more.
You did more than anyone could have asked for, Nagato.
I should practice swimming. I want to be better prepared if we find ourselves in this sort of situation again.
As do I.
... There's a bit of seaweed in your hair. And I think one of the Morganas is heading back to finish us off.
Ha, my hair, and then the Funayūrei? You have your priorities straight, Kanchou.
I just like to see you smile.
@BATTLE
I heard you have been acquainting yourself with our new guests, Nagato. How are they?
As well as could be expected, Kanchou. That's the head medical officer's assessment.
A few are still in the sickbay with injuries received during the attack. A few others have traumatic neurosis.
I spoke to one of the survivors. They weren't prepared for this sort of attack at all.
Foolishness, to put to sea without good armaments. The Funayūrei don't spare civilians.
I was hoping to learn more about the Funayūrei from the survivors' stories, but few are inclined to talk about it.

Fields.MenuText: Be careful and polite, of course, but any information you could glean from them would be useful.
Leave the information gathering to me. I'll talk to the survivors. They seem intimidated by my rank.
Leave our guests be. It's only natural they wouldn't want to talk of the sinking of their ship.

Fields.DialogueText: They're our guests, Kanchou. I will treat them with all due respect, of course.
Hmm. I could argue Belles are equally impressive, but I suppose we don't have a rank to boast of.
Sometimes painful things are necessary for the greater good, Kanchou. We need more information to use against the Funayūrei.
I was surprised that the crew and passengers who survived are almost as varied as our own crew.
Wars like these make for strange bedfellows, even among civilians.
What are we going to do with them, Kanchou?
We'll likely leave them at the next port, in the care of the Protection Force. They will be able to make it home from there.
That seems reasonable. I hope I can uncover some useful information from them before then.
Speaking of Funayūrei, I can sense one prowling the ocean nearby. Are you ready for a hunt?
Always.
@BATTLE
Nagato! Where are you off to? What's that under your arm?
Oh, hello, Kanchou! It's a Go board - I borrowed it from the medical officer, Miss Wong.
Have you ever played Go, Kanchou? It's a wonderful game for keeping one's strategic skills sharp.

Fields.MenuText: I have, but it's been some time since I played last.
I think I've heard of it...?
I hardly have time for eating, much less games, Nagato.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, I hadn't had the chance to play in a while either. I had no idea Miss Wong played it until earlier today.
If you'd ever like to learn more, Miss Wong does a wonderful job of explaining the rules.
Games like this can be useful, Kanchou. They're not just a frivolity.
We should play a game sometime. I was just heading down to visit Moto-san.
Moto-san?
Moto Kiyoshi is one of our guests from the wreck. He's a businessman, and bought passage on the ill-fated vessel.
Ah, I remember you mentioning there was a Japanese man among the survivors. Have you found out anything useful from him?
No, Kanchou, unfortunately. He was in his cabin during the attack and didn't see much. It was luck he survived.
I'm sorry if you think I'm being frivolous by playing a game at a time like this. But I'd very much like to hear any news I've missed from Japan, and hopefully sharpen my Go skills in the process.
No, I'm glad you're getting along well with our guests. I just wanted to ask you something.
What is it, Kanchou?
*ALARM*
... It looks like your game and my question will have to wait.
@BATTLE
You've done it again. I'm afraid I'll have to concede the victory to you, Nagato-sama.
Nagato...?
Ah. I'm sorry to interrupt. I didn't expect you to have Mr. Moto in your quarters, Nagato.
Forgive me for the indiscretion, but I wanted a quiet place to play, and it would be a breach of etiquette to bring him into the wardroom.
I don't believe we have been formally introduced. My name is Moto Kiyoshi, and I'm one of the fortunate souls Nagato saved.

Fields.MenuText: I'm the captain. It's a pleasure to meet you, Mr. Moto.
I'm Nagato's captain.
I'd prefer you didn't command all of Nagato's time, Mr. Moto. She has duties to attend to.

Fields.DialogueText: Kanchou is the best kanchou any Belle could hope to have, and is the one deserving of your thanks, Moto-san.
Choosing my kanchou was the best move I ever made, Moto-san.
Kanchou, don't be sharp with my guest. You needn't worry about me.
I hope you're treating Nagato with the respect she deserves, Mr. Moto.
Anything else would be unthinkable, Kanchou.
I'm glad to hear it. Nagato, I was hoping to speak with you alone.
It will have to wait. A Morgana just slipped into nearby waters. I think she may be hunting. We have to stop her.
Very well. You'd best return to your quarters, Mr. Moto.
@BATTLE
I will end this battle quickly! I have more important things to do today!
@BATTLE
Kanchou, are you all right? You retreated to your quarters very quickly after that fight. I thought it went well...
Mm. I'm fine. I just have a bit of a headache.
Ah, I saw you hit your head on that control panel when the bridge was shaken.
Mhm.
Have you been to see the ship's doctors? You could have a concussion.
I'm fine. You don't have to worry about me.
... Are you upset with me, Kanchou? About me spending so much time with Moto-san?

Fields.MenuText: No, I'm just tired, Nagato. But I appreciate your concern.
It just feels like we haven't had many conversations lately.
You do spend... a lot of time with him. It's clear you find him very interesting.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Kanchou. I know I haven't been as focused on my duties as I am normally - I apologize, and give you my word I'll do better from now on.
You know you are the most important person in my life, Kanchou. I apologize if I've been neglecting you.
He is interesting, but I think my interest in him has more to do with my homesickness. Still, I apologize for not spending more time with you - our partnership should be most important.
There's a lot we need to talk about, Kanchou. I'm sorry for burdening you with unfinished conversations.
Can we start with whatever you planned to tell me back before running into the burning ships?
That was some time ago... what was I was worrying about?
Ah... yes.
... It just occurred to me, that day, that it would only be so long until one nation or another tried to use the Funayūrei.
Use the Morganas? You mean ally with them?
Yes. Look at how incredible they are. Their ships seem nearly indestructible; they strike everywhere, often without warning...
Allied with a human understanding of both our world and the weaknesses of the nations, they could dominate the seas.
A human power throwing themselves behind the Morganas would be disturbing, but it's unlikely. They rarely even communicate with us.
But... it's only so long until someone tries. Especially with the war on land.
And if someone does try... how long will the Protection Force's unity last? Once someone breaks the trust?
... That's a good question, Nagato.
Hello, Kanchou! Could we have a moment of your time?
If you're not especially busy, Kanchou.
I have some time. What is it, Mr. Moto?
I... may have some information vital to the future of the Protection Force. I saw something during the attack.
Nagato told me you didn't see much. I thought you were in your cabin.
It's true, I was... most of the time. But I saw... something.
Well, what is it?
... It is difficult to speak of it, Kanchou. Perhaps you understand?

Fields.MenuText: I understand, but keeping it to yourself won't help anyone.
I understand it may be difficult, but I need to know.
Get to the point.

Fields.DialogueText: He says he finds it too difficult to talk about it at sea. He fears retaliation from the Funayūrei.
He fears retaliation from the Funayūrei if he discusses it now, while still at sea.
Kanchou! You shouldn't be so rude.
I know my information may be important. I would like to speak with a higher-ranking representative of the Protection Force as soon as possible.
Kanchou, there's a Funayūrei following us.
Get below, Mr. Moto. We'll worry about your information later.
@BATTLE
What do you think? How trustworthy do you think Mr. Moto is? His behavior seems a little strange.
I will admit, his fear of speaking of what he saw because he thinks the Funayūrei could hear...
It's not sound logic. The Funayūrei are strong, but not omniscient.
The Funayūrei are also crafty. Just because we haven't yet had proof of them listening in on us, doesn't mean that they aren't.
However, paranoia can be a symptom of battle neurosis. His information may be valid, even if his fears are delusional.
That's true. I'll speak to Command about the situation, and see if the brass wants to talk to him.
I'm a bit sad to see our guests go, even if it's good to send them back to their homes.
You won't have to say goodbye to Mr. Moto.
Why? Did one of the admirals want to talk to him?
We have new orders. I - damn, is that a French ship off the bow?
No, Kanchou, that's a Funayūrei. She looks like she's angling for the port...
All hands to stations! At least we will be able to accomplish something today.
@BATTLE
Hah! She'll think twice before trying to tangle with us again. But what are our new orders, Kanchou?
We're to keep Mr. Moto aboard and rendezvous with a member of the Protection Force brass.
They believe he may know something useful after all, then. What do you think?

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad that something will come of the tragedy, if he truly knows something useful.
I don't like being given the task of ferrying around businessmen, no matter what they know.
I don't like the man, I don't believe him, and I don't want him on my ship.

Fields.DialogueText: I am, too. I wish he would share this information with us as well.
I understand, but sometimes utility missions like this are even more important than combat.
You should put aside your feelings for now, Kanchou. For the good of the fleet.
In any event, we can't argue with orders.
You get to keep your Go partner.
I hadn't thought of that. That's definitely an upside.
I'm glad it makes you happy.
Incoming!
Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Kanchou! You're bleeding!
I... oh. Some shrapnel from that last shell, I think. It's not too bad, is it?
I... I mean... Kanchou...
You know... you really don't need to be so formal. You... can call me by my first name.
Kanchou, I don't think now is the time to...
I know you prefer to use kanchou. Is there any reason why? Why do you prefer the formality?
Y-you're my Kanchou. It's respectful.
I respect you, but I don't call you ma'am, or Lady, or any of the titles I could use. Would you rather I use a title?
That really isn't necessary, Kanchou.
I'll do it. If that's what would make you happy.
You know, I think the blood loss is getting to you. Why don't we get you to sick bay?
Very well... Miss Nagato?
I told you, that's not necessary.
All right... all right.
Kanchou! How are you feeling?
Better. A bit sore, but that's all. What are you... Ouch!
Oh! I'm sorry, I didn't mean to hurt you...
No, no, it's fine. ... You've never hugged me before.
I was... Well. I was scared I was going to lose you, Kanchou. You lost quite a bit of blood. And seeing you make such a speedy recovery, well... it just made me happy.
It would take more than a little piece of shrapnel to get rid of me, Nagato.
That's good to hear. And regarding the use of your name...
I did babble on that subject for a while, didn't I?
Again, you had lost quite a bit of blood.
I am at my best when I am disciplined and focused. Observing proper etiquette assists me in that mission. You want me at my best, don't you?
Of course. I didn't mean to ask you to discard your propriety. I only wanted to let you know you have the right to call me whatever you wish.
Thank you, Kanchou.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
How have things been running? Smoothly, I hope.
... Mostly. More or less. Well. No. Not especially smoothly at all.
What's happened?
The crew is getting restless. The general sentiment is that we're on a useless mission, and we'd do better to be hunting Funayūrei.
We're doing plenty of fighting. What's the root of their problem?
... I think it's Moto-san, Kanchou. The fact that he's a businessman who has ties to the land wars and doesn't hide it.
I thought you liked him.
I enjoy his company, but he seems to have little sense. He doesn't give thought to the ways his words might affect those around him.
He's a living, breathing reminder of the conflicts everyone has to put aside to function in the Protection Force.
I see what you mean. He flaunts his loyalties?
He brags about Japan's military. He's charming, but sometimes he just doesn't know when to be quiet.
Hm. We received orders to chase a pair of Morganas from the coastline, so hopefully a good fight will calm the crew.
Keep on eye on Mr. Moto for me, would you?
I already am, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
Hello, Kanchou.
Hello, Nagato. A pleasure, as always.
Would you like some tea?

Fields.MenuText: That sounds wonderful. Thank you, Nagato.
No, thank you. I'm not fond of it.
I don't have time to sit and have tea right now, I'm afraid.

Fields.DialogueText: It's my pleasure. Here you are, Kanchou.
I don't understand how anyone can dislike matcha.
I understand. Is the fleet pressing you for more reports?
I just had a question. It's a bit of a foolish one, but I can't believe I never asked it.
What is it?
Is that sword you wear ceremonial?
My uchigatana? Not exactly, Kanchou. I know how to use it, though I haven't had the occasion to do so for some time.
I can't imagine you running around and fighting with a sword, especially in those clothes and shoes.
I'm a capable fencer, Kanchou, even in these shoes. But it's true it's not something I do regularly. It's a last resort.
How do you mean?
If we were attacked and boarded, it would be my responsibility to defend this ship to the end. To protect my kanchou and crew.
I see...
Don't put on that expression, Kanchou. It's an unlikely event, given the Funayūrei's current habits. But if one ever did step on board...
Well, she would be at an extreme disadvantage. This ship is me, after all.
Nagato... do you want a pistol? I could requisition one from the armory for you.
No, Kanchou, but thank you. The guns already installed in my ship are enough. My uchigatana is just for times of desperation.
I see. Well, hopefully, you won't be forced to use it today. There‘s another Morgana on our tail.
@BATTLE
I don't understand your love of the Washington Naval Treaty, Nagato. It was written to strangle our country's navy.
I don't love it, but it's an important measure, and a good reminder of what makes this war so dangerous.
We're fighting something we won't ever be able to make treaties with, that we don't understand at all.
Am I interrupting something?
Not at all. Kiyoshi-san was just leaving. I don't believe our game can progress any further today.
Are you running from a debate? How unlike you, Nagato-sama.
You have spent the last fifteen minutes coyly implying I am an ideological traitor to my country. That's not a debate.
I told you to show Nagato respect. You may be our guest, but you owe her a massive debt.
... I apologize, Nagato-sama, Kanchou. I got ahead of myself. I should not have made implications about your loyalties.
I know you are loyal to the Emperor above all else. I would point out, however, that that treaty of yours ended up doing very little.
I will take your opinion into account. Good day, Kiyoshi-san.

Fields.MenuText: I take it you and Mr. Moto are having ideological differences.
I don't like him.
You were supposed to be keeping an eye on him, not arguing with him.

Fields.DialogueText: It was unavoidable, though that argument wasn't. I should have handled it better...
Many of his viewpoints are valid. It is only that they are viewpoints that must be set aside, in this moment, for the greater good.
... You would be surprised how hard that can be when dealing with him, Kanchou.
Perhaps decreeing a "no talk of politics while playing Go" rule is in order.
That's a good idea. I do regret snapping at him. I should be trying to resolve the tension on this ship, not add to it.
Well, not to add to your cares, but there is a Morgana a few hundred kilometers away.
Hunting a Morgana? That's the opposite of a care, Kanchou. We're well-prepared.
@BATTLE
Sound the alarm! Morganas rapidly approaching!
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
What in the hell was that shouting after the battle?
Moto-san and Officer Wong got into an altercation. He was on deck, watching during the battle.

Fields.MenuText: Damn Mr. Moto! I can't believe how much trouble one man can cause.
Miss Wong should know better, she's supposed to be a responsible officer!
Who started the fight? What was it about?

Fields.DialogueText: The chaos an individual seeking conflict can cause should never be overlooked, Kanchou.
I agree. However, Moto-san was definitely pushing her buttons.
Moto-san started it, I believe.
The fight was over nationality. I believe Moto-san made some derogatory comments about her country, and her personal integrity.
I regret more each day that Command saddled us with this man. However, fighting with passengers is not...
Befitting an officer. I know. I left her discipline to you, and had a stern talk with Mr. Moto.
I don't know if that will do much good. Next time you talk to him, tell him I don't want civilians on deck, ever, during a battle.
Hai!
I think we should prepare for battle, Kanchou.
You're sensing Morganas?
Yes.
@BATTLE
What has you looking so sad, Nagato? We survived another battle.
I'm not sad, Kanchou. Only... pensive.

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure that isn't another word for being sad?
All right. Just know that if something is bothering you, I'm always here to listen.
Don't get to overthinking things and lose focus on our mission.

Fields.DialogueText: Hah, you know it's not. It's not a lie, I'm not sad, but I suppose I am troubled.
I know, Kanchou. And... I suppose there is something bothering me.
I won't. I won't let it interfere... I just have a personal worry.
I don't mean to trouble you...
It's not a trouble. Speak your mind.
Hah! Is that an order from my kanchou?
It's a suggestion from someone who cares for you.
I was just thinking about my argument with Moto-san, when he said that, at least, I was loyal to the Emperor...
What about it?
I am loyal. I love my country. But... at this point, I recognize that fighting the Funayūrei is more important than loyalty to my country.
You've said it yourself. This is the most important theater of war in human history.
Human conflicts don't come close to comparing. I know it. I believe it. And I believe in what we're doing.
I know.
His words just shook me.
I believe the Protection Force is doing what is best, for what it's worth. And I have news that may lift your spirits.
What is it?
We're to rendezvous with another ship, and hand Mr. Moto off to her captain.
There have been two Funayūrei following us for some time, Kanchou. They're armed to the teeth. Take a look.
Hmm. We seem to have been running into a greater number of Morganas than usual since taking Mr. Moto aboard.
You think they might be after him, like he feared? I confess, with the recent troubles with him...
His worries slipped my mind.
That's understandable. But perhaps his concerns were valid. They could have intercepted our communications...
If multiple Morganas have been sent to get rid of him, that means speed is of the essence. The sooner we hand him off, the sooner the Morganas will lose interest.
Then we'd best dispatch these Morganas as soon as possible.
@BATTLE
You don't look well, Nagato.
I don't feel well, Kanchou. I'm not... working correctly. Our continued high rates of speed are beginning to wear on me.
It was a malfunction in one of the boilers. The engine crew is working on fixing it now.
... Ugh.
Do you feel all damage to the ship physically?
Yes... no? It's hard to explain, and it's not something I like to dwell on. The ship isn't flesh, but it's still a part of me.
I don't always feel damage. I was built for this, after all. But when I do... it can hurt a bit.
Is it the same for most Belles?
I can't speak for all Belles. We're not entirely similar creatures, Kanchou. Some sleep more than others, some eat more than others, some feel more than others. You get the idea.
That's interesting.
*ALARM*
Looks as if a few more Morganas have caught up to us.
@BATTLE
You truly believe the Protection Force is what is best for Japan?
I do. If the navies of the world were still divided, we would have little hope against a force like the Funayūrei.
I thought I banned you from my decks, Mr. Moto.
During sea battles, I believe, Kanchou.
Hm.
In any event, I believe I owe you an apology. I let my temper get the best of me, and I disrespected your and Nagato-sama's hospitality.
You did.
Nagato rightly scolded me for my shameful behavior. I will do my best to stay out of the way for the rest of the voyage, Kanchou.
Thank you, Moto-san. Now, I have to speak to Kanchou in private, if you don't mind.

Fields.MenuText: That apology was gratifying.
Do you think there was any sincerity in that apology?
That man is a serpent. His regret is false.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad. And it was elegant, as well.
I'm not sure. He seemed sincere, but I don't think I'm such a persuasive person that I can change a man's entire outlook in a few pointed conversations.
Strongly worded, but I would agree he has shown himself to be volatile, at the very least.
We should continue to keep an eye on him, in any event.
Agreed.
Kanchou, there's another Funayūrei... ! I can... hear her...?
Nagato? Should we prepare for a fight?
Yes. I believe she's hijacking our customary broadcasting frequencies. She's broadcasting to our communications array.
What is she saying?
... Nothing... nothing that makes sense. It's garbled and... disturbing. I worry for those who have to listen to it. We should be careful.
@BATTLE
Our last fight with Despair... is not something I ever wish to repeat. I could feel those radio frequencies radiating through me...
Those messages she was broadcasting put several of my communications officers in sick bay. They say it was like the sound of fear itself.
... Did you hear it, Kanchou? What did it make you think of?

Fields.MenuText: I don't want to talk about it.
It made me think of death, and the dark.
Hearing it made me feel like I was drowning. It felt like I couldn't breathe.

Fields.DialogueText: I... I understand. It's hard to speak of.
Cold hands and a sailor's burial... I could feel a murmur of that.
... That's similar to what I felt. But I won't let you drown.
What did it make you think of?
... All the fears of my crew. And more. Drowning. The crushing weight of the water, breaking me apart into so many little pieces... the chaos of the deep.
The chaos of war. Failing my country. Failing you.
It doesn't us do any good to dwell on these things.
... No. No, it doesn't. We chased her off. That is all that matters. She was just another Funayūrei, with a disturbing trick.
One we should warn the Protection Force about.
I'm certain they've heard plenty of stories like ours.
Doubtless. At least we're getting wise to their tricks.
@BATTLE
Hmm. And it looks like it's time to wise up again...
With the delay, we will likely be late to our rendezvous.
Hmm. That's true.
The ship's captain will contact us within the hour, most likely.
Well, I'm glad that the rendezvous won't be delayed by much. Hopefully Mr. Moto will get along better with the new crew than ours.
I managed to extract a promise from Moto-san that he would be on his best behavior.
That will hopefully stop him from picking arguments with the officers, at least.
Unfortunately, we may have to strain the engines again. I'm sensing several Funayūrei, and they're moving toward us quickly.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, the crew is still shaken up by the Funayūrei broadcasting over the radios. The ones who didn't hear it directly heard talk of it from others.
I know. It's impossible to keep anything like that quiet in a ship.
I'm worried about our crew's recent performance... and their morale. Our fight is hard enough without the Funayūrei trying to get in their heads.
You're right. But there's little we can do about it, besides putting it behind us.
I have an idea. I heard talk of a Funayūrei nearby, picking off local fishermen and merchant ships.
The crew's morale shouldn't be overlooked. Right now, I think despair is eating away at them. I believe that the more battles we win, the more they'll pull out of their present funk.
I see.
And perhaps we could plan some sort of celebration after our victory. That might lift their spirits even higher.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds like an excellent idea.
Going into a fight thinking victory is secure makes me uneasy.
I'm still not sure it would be a good use of our time, especially if we have to divert our course.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you think so. I hope it works.
I agree that it normally isn't the best mindset. But I believe we're equal to this task.
We would hardly have to divert our course. Plus, once the crew is in better spirits, I believe we'll make even better time than we are now.
Please, Kanchou. I truly think this plan could help.
Very well. We'll set our course for this Funayūrei.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
We should share a meal later, Kanchou. There's something I've been meaning to--
Pardon my interruption, but could I speak with you both in my cabin? I have some information I wish to impart to you.
Very well, lead the way. We'll speak of it later, Nagato.
... What are you doing, Moto-san?! Get your hands off of me, I--
Be quiet, or I shoot. I don't want to do this, Nagato-sama, but I will if your kanchou doesn't listen very carefully to what I have to say.
What the hell?!
Listen, Kanchou. When the ship approaches, you will tell your crew to ready the artillery. You will shoot early, before it is in range...
You're trying to break the treaty. The INPF is stronger than that. A single incident between two ships won't...
Be quiet.

Fields.MenuText: Get your hands off her!
I won't fire at another Protection Force ship, no matter what you threaten.
Nagato's right. It would take more than a single shot to break the treaty.

Fields.DialogueText: You've miscalculated, Moto. You're not thinking clearly, to think you can get the upper hand here.
My kanchou has integrity, unlike some people. So shoot me if you feel like it.
I know you think it's for the good of our country, Moto, but the Funayūrei will destroy Japan just as they would destroy any country which stood alone.
And you do realize your bullets will do nothing to hurt me, don't you?
Maybe not, but you would do anything to protect your kanchou--
*PUNCH*
Augh! You--!
Don't you dare threaten my kanchou.
You forgot the same rule of combat as the Funayūrei. Don't engage an enemy on their home ground.
*SOME TIME LATER*
That was some decent self-defense, Nagato.
It's just a shame he didn't give me the chance to use my sword. Are you all right?
He didn't even touch me. Thanks to you.
Here's the pistol he had. He's still breathing, but he will likely require some medical attention. The Protection Force ship is approaching. We should prepare to receive her.
And explain what the hell just happened...
Speaking of...
I'll put him under lock and key, Kanchou. Somewhere with a nice view of the action.
@BATTLE
Kanchou!
It's good to see you too, Nagato, but we've hardly been apart for long... you're squeezing my ribs a little hard.
Ah. My apologies, Kanchou. Just, while you were talking with the other kanchou, I had time to sit. My thoughts kept returning to what would have happened had Moto managed to shoot you...

Fields.MenuText: I was never in any danger of that, thanks to you.
I don't like the idea either. I'm glad I had you by my side.
It was a close call.

Fields.DialogueText: But you were. I should have acted quicker!
Me too. But I should have acted quicker, I shouldn't have even let him grab me...
Too close for comfort.
I should have suspected his plans. Moto told me he believed Japan was being taken advantage of by the Protection Force.
Talking is one thing. You had no way of knowing he would try to take action.
I'm just glad we stopped him. The thought of losing you...
He clearly wasn't thinking things through, to think he could take a Belle hostage.
That's true. How did the meeting with the kanchou go?
Well enough. He asked us to chase away a few nearby Morganas. While we take care of them, he'll escort Moto to the Protection Force brass.
I doubt he knows anything truly important. He could have had ill intentions to begin with. Or, perhaps this voyage pushed him to these extremes.
You know, he kept a radio in his room. Maybe it was the exposure to that Funayūrei... I suppose there's no way for us to know.
It isn't our concern any longer. We've exposed his intentions. It's up to Command to decide what happens to him.
You're right. To the hunt, then.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
You know, of all our struggles, I hate uncertainty most of all.
I can understand that.
Would you like some tea, Kanchou?

Fields.MenuText: Of course, thank you.
I suppose I'll take some, just this once.
No, thank you.

Fields.DialogueText: Here you go. It's the last of my matcha, for now. I'll have to request some more the next time we go into port.
Hah, thank you for enduring it, for my sake. It's important to me.
Hmm, I still don't understand how anyone could dislike tea, but I suppose we all have different tastes.
I have noticed that uncertainty bothers you.
I was afraid of admitting it when we first met. Afraid of seeming inexperienced. Afraid of being inexperienced. Afraid of letting you down.
I'm less afraid now. But I still hate uncertainty. I've been struggling with something for a while now, and I realize... I can't sit around, wondering, any longer.
Nagato...?
I realized how happy I was that you are my kanchou...
And I realized, that we Belles are supremely lucky. We get to choose those who lead us. We have a hand in our fates. I should take advantage of such luck.
What do you mean?
I... I've realized... I... I have feelings for you, Kanchou. I'm sorry, I know this is too forward, but...
It's all right, Nagato.
It... it is...?

Fields.MenuText: I feel the same way about you.
I've been struggling with feelings of my own.
You really took the leap to tell me, without realizing I felt the same way?

Fields.DialogueText: I... Really? You do? Truly? I... I don't know what to say.
You - you have? You feel the same way about me? I...
I... I... Hah. I suppose I should have realized.
I'm grateful, always, every day, that you chose me.
Choosing you was the best decision I ever made. I know I will never regret it... but the Funayūrei certainly will.
